repnme.cdata!: Jamaica - Reform of Secondary Education Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability highly likely, and the institutional
            development impact substantial. Regardless of success,
            lessons convey the need for deepening the reform in such
            areas as: greater emphasis on high standards for all
            students, particularly those under-performing; greater
            support to schools to address deficiencies; and, improvement
            in the implementation process, with emphasis on performance
            indicators, and greater accountability. Most importantly,
            since the project was designed almost a decade ago, the
            focus was to provide the necessary inputs, and strengthen
            management capacity. However, this supply-driven model,
            needs to be complemented by a demand-driven approach, in
            order for the reform to take root at the school level.
            Regarding the social policy analysis (SPA), lessons
            stipulate that building analytic capacity is a slow, and
            incremental process, which requires careful diagnosis, for
            activities to reach the required cumulative effect. The
            success of SPA lies in that it reached the broad network of
            people involved in generating data, analyzing it, and
            developing policy, and, because analysts had access to data
            for training, and research purposes. However, with respect
            to training indications suggest that demand is likely to be
            high; that participants should be relatively homogeneous in
            terms of mathematical background, computer literacy, and
            access to computer facilities; and, that participants should
            be encouraged to enroll program-wide, rather than individual
            courses, to enhance curriculum skills.

repnme.cdata!: Jamaica - Reform of Secondary Education Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project will:  (a) improve the
            quality, efficiency and equity of lower secondary education;
            (b) strengthen the capacity of the Ministry of Education and
            Culture (MOEC) to plan and monitor the impact of the reform;
            and (c) strengthen the government's  capacity to
            undertake sophisticated social policy analysis to formulate
            targeted social programs.  The project comprises three main
            components:  (1) secondary reform support which includes:
            (a) the introduction of a common curriculum; (b) related
            pre-service and in-service training; (c) textbooks; (d)
            educational support materials; (e) physical infrastructure
            for schools; and (f) studies and pilot programs for
            secondary education.  (2) Evaluation and management
            strengthening which includes:  (a) rationalizing the
            examination system; (b) establishing a secondary reform
            management team to ensure that the reform is adequately
            supported; (c) conducting a public awareness campaign to
            inform key stakeholders about the benefits of the reform;
            (d) developing an evaluation system to monitor the impact of
            the new curriculum; and (e) preparing the second five-year
            phase of the reform.  (3) Social policy analysis which will
            improve the capacity of the government to undertake
            sophisticated social policy analysis and formulate more
            effective and targeted social sector programs.

734730.trustfund: TF028065-CANADIAN CONSLT. COOP. PROGRAM,TF039096-JAMAICA - ESW ROSE AND STUDENT LOAN,TF024815-REFORM OF SECONDARY EDUCATION PROJECT,TF021406-REFORM OF SECONDARY EDUCATION PROJECT,TF023021-PHRD-INTEGRATED PRIMARY HEALTH CARE

repnme.cdata!:
Jamaica - A study of the reform of
            secondary education : fourth World Bank - 1990

abstracts.cdata!:
This study summarizes the deliberations
            and conclusions of a number of consultants who were invited
            to consider proposals for the reform of secondary education
            in Jamaica. For a six-month period in 1989 and a one-month
            period in 1990, the study group addressed the terms of
            reference prepared by the Ministry of Education, i.e. the
            rationalization of existing institutional types, development
            of new curricula, and the feasibility of a unified lower
            secondary cycle. In 1983, a United Nations Educational,
            Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) report on
            education in Jamaica had suggested a common curriculum for
            the lower cycle of secondary schools.  The study begins with
            an overview in chapter one of the present system, the
            historical forces which still shape it, and the major
            problems which need to be addressed. The basic reasons were
            outlined in chapter two. Recommendations for focus and
            balance in the curriculum are presented in chapters three
            and four. The main objective of the current reform of the
            Jamaican secondary education system is the definition of a
            common curriculum for all the students of grades seven-nine
            is presented in chapter five. A plan for teacher education
            and staff development is presented in chapter six.  Finally,
            in chapter seven, an enhanced operational role for school
            boards within the context of strong central planning by the
            Ministry of Education is described. An incremental strategy
            for implementation is presented as a guide to the work of
            school boards and the Ministers and officials of the
            Ministry in the task of introducing and implementing the reforms.

docna.cdata!:
Jamaica - A study of the reform of secondary
            education : fourth World Bank - 1990

Jamaica - A study of the reform
            of secondary education : fourth World Bank - 1990 (Vol. 2)
